SubSections.Title: Attack Resolution
SubSections.Content: Roll to see if you hit, then deal your damage to all hit targets. The hit target is defined by the target's Defense Target. [target's evasion - your Graze Range] to 20 is a hit, [target's evasion - your Graze Range] to [target's evasion - 1] is a graze, [target's evasion] and above is a strike, everything below [target's evasion - your Graze Range] is a miss. In case of a natural [21 - Crit Range] to 20, it becomes a crit instead. A graze deals [original damage -/ 2] damage. A crit rerolls all damage dice and takes the sum, unless the crit effect is overriden. The target can choose to turn any miss into either a graze or strike. The result of this roll is additionally influenced by advantage/disadvantage, cover, and unaware/hidden.

SubSections.Title: Natural Rolls And Modifiers
SubSections.Content: The natural result of a roll does not take into account any modifiers (such as accuracy). In all other cases modifiers are taken into account (such as by adding your accuracy to the result).

SubSections.Title: Advantage/Disadvantage
SubSections.Content: Each instance of advantage and disadvantage cancel each other out. Then, if you still have instances of advantage left, add 1d20 for each instance to the attack roll and take the highest result. If you instead still have instances of disadvantage left, add 1d20 for each instance and take the lowest result.

SubSections.Title: Ranged Against Melee
SubSections.Content: All ranged attacks gain disadvantage against combatants close to them.

SubSections.Title: Cover
SubSections.Content: The GM can decide depending on the description of an attack, whether something can provide a target with partial or full cover to your attack. In case of a partial cover, the GM can decide to apply a negative bonus based on how much the target is covered. In case of full cover, you automatically miss against it.

SubSections.Title: Unaware And Hidden
SubSections.Content: Whenever you make an attack against a combatant that cannot perceive you (see, hear, smell or otherwise sense), you are considered hidden from that combatant. If a combatant is unaware of your presence, it will be considered surprised against your attacks until it becomes aware of your presence. If you attack a surprised combatant, or if you make a simple melee attack against a combatant that you are hidden from, then the attack gains advantage against the combatant. If a combatant is hidden from you, you can try to guess its location and attack a random tile of your choice. Just because you are hidden from a combatant, doesn't necessarily mean it is unaware of your presence. Directly after you use an attack action, the targets and those around will likely become aware of your presence before you can make a second attack.

SubSections.Title: Damage
SubSections.Content: You usually deal damage as part of an attack, but rarely features allow you to deal damage without one. Damage is first rolled (if applicable), and then modified depending on the damage types, success level, conditions, and shield, according to the damage modifier order.

SubSections.Title: Damage Modifier Order
SubSections.Content: Damage modifiers are applied in the following order (descending).

SubSections.Title: Damage Type Reduction
SubSections.Content: When you deal damage against a combatant with a reduction against one or more damage types of the damage, the damage is reduced by the highest applicable reduction down to a minimum of 1. A general damage reduction works against all damage types.

SubSections.Title: Damage Type Weakness
SubSections.Content: When you deal damage against a combatant with a weakness against one or more damage types of the damage, the damage is increased by half rounded down.

SubSections.Title: Damage Type Resistance
SubSections.Content: When you deal damage against a combatant with a resistance against one or more damage types of the damage, the damage is halved rounded down.

SubSections.Title: Damage Type Immunity
SubSections.Content: When you deal damage against a combatant with an immunity against one or more damage types of the damage, the damage is reduced to 0.

SubSections.Title: Explode
SubSections.Content: If damage explodes, after rolling damage, you reroll any damage dice that rolled maximum damage and add it to your previous total. If it rolled maximum damage again, you repeat rerolling it until it rolls something different than the maximum.
